thread.title_full: Nissan to decide next month if it will produce new Qashqai at Sunderland

author: Mike Kelly
title: Nissan to decide next month if it will produce new Qashqai at Sunderland
text:
Nissan to decide next month if it will produce new Qashqai at Sunderland 12:14, 21 Oct 2016 Decision could have a massive effect not just on the plant but on the regional economy, business bosses warn   David Parry/PA Wire Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn 
Car giants Nissan will decide next month on whether to produce the next Qashqai SUV model at its Sunderland plant following the UK’s decision to leave the European Union, its Chief Executive Carlos Ghosn said. 
Mr Ghosn comments follow his meeting last week with Prime Minister Theresa May in which he warned that leaving the EU could halt investment on Wearside. 
The factory, which builds the popular Qashqai SUV and many other models, is Britain’s largest car plant, producing 475,000 vehicles last year, of which 80% were exported. 
It is also one of the North east’s biggest employers with around 7,000 staff working there. Leave campaigners celebrate as they win the vote in Sunderland during the North East region European Union referendum count on June 24, 2016 
Mr Ghosn said: “We’re not asking for any advantage (from the British government), but we don’t want to lose any competitiveness no matter what the discussions.” 
He said he had received reassurance that the British government would be “extremely cautious” in “preserving the competitiveness” of the Sunderland plant . 
“As long as I have this guarantee ... I can look at the future of Sunderland with more ease,” he said. 
Production of the next Qashqai model is expected to begin around 2018 or 2019. 
Businesses have been concerned that Britain is headed towards a “hard Brexit”, which would leave it outside the single market and facing tariffs of up to 10% on car exports. 
If Nissan decides not to produce the next Qashqai SUV at Sunderland it would be a massive blow for the regional economy. 
And those who campaigned for the UK to stay in the EU might think it would be bitterly ironic. 
On the night of the EU referendum it was the Sunderland vote which was overwhelmingly for Leave which first hinted at a win for Brexit. 
This was despite concerns expressed in the campaign about the future of Nissan which were dismissed by Brexiteers as part of ‘Project Fear’.
